entry.title: Why People Come Before Process and Technology in the SAP BTP Journey
entry.content:
When people talk about SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) or any transformation project, the conversation often begins with technologyâ€”data models, extensions, integrations, and AI. But in my experience, the real magic of BTP doesnâ€™t just come from its capabilities; it comes from the people who gather around it.

A platform becomes powerful when it inspires collaboration. Thatâ€™s where community building comes in. Whether youâ€™re a developer, architect, or business user, being part of a thriving community accelerates learning, drives adoption, and sparks innovation in ways no single project team can achieve alone.

Who I Am

Iâ€™m SAP BTP DevOps & AI Manager at Bluestonex (member of the SAP AppHaus Network), a mentor guiding SAP Tech professionals at Modish Tech (my own digital brand), and a trustee for The Sanatan Parivar charity, aiming to bring communities together.

Iâ€™ve been fortunate to see SAP BTP evolve from its very beginnings, and Iâ€™m thankful to the organisations I worked forâ€”and continue to work withâ€”for allowing me to explore it right from when it was first introduced. 

My passion lies in bridging innovation with community impactâ€”using technology not just to solve business challenges, but also to empower people. Over the years, Iâ€™ve seen how focusing on people first changes the trajectory of projects, communities, and careers.

If youâ€™d like to continue the conversation or just say hello, you can find me on LinkedIn.

Now, back to the topic...

Technology Is Only Part of the Equation

SAP BTP offers incredible capabilities that reshape business operations. But these tools are only as effective as the people who imagine, build, and sustain them. Without shared understanding, collaboration, and knowledge transfer, even the most advanced solutions risk becoming underutilisedâ€”or worse, becoming that â€œcool proof of conceptâ€ everyone forgets about six months later.

The People-First Advantage

So what does â€œpeople firstâ€ look like in the SAP BTP journey?

  • Confidence Through Enablement â€“ These days, enablement is the key. With an ever-changing tech stackâ€”and especially in the SAP ecosystem, where constant branding and rebranding often push older content into the binâ€”newcomers are left confused about where to start. Classic example is SAP Integration Suite in the community is known by different names, CPI, IS, CI... everyone has their own version. We still refer Work Zone as the launchpad.  These are just few examples, I hear a lot from my mentees. This is why consistent enablement matters. Without it, people struggle to build confidence; with it, they can navigate the shifts, embrace the new, and grow faster.
  • Knowledge Sharing â€“ Empowering teams through open discussions, blogs, and mentorship ensures that expertise doesnâ€™t sit in silos. It's easy to explore technology and build a proof of concept individually. But if we multiply this, it's even more powerful. This means everyone in a team is doing it, think about the productivity and work delivered by  the team.
  • Collaboration Over Isolation â€“ The best BTP outcomes Iâ€™ve seen came from cross-functional teams and communities working together, not from lone experts. Let's be real, you cannot do everything on your own. You need people with expertise in different areas. 
  • Innovation Through Conversation â€“ Some of the most creative BTP use cases Iâ€™ve seen didnâ€™t start with a specification sheet; they started with people brainstorming and challenging each other. An example of this is the SAP BTP Monitor, which the team at Bluestonex delivered when we had nothing where we can see the SAP BTP consumption. Now SAP have come up with this option in the cockpit. There are many gaps, and people at Bluestonex fill these gaps with apps, all that starts with a conversation!

Rethinking the Balance

Process and technology will always matterâ€”but theyâ€™re accelerators, not starting points. When you put people first, you create an environment where processes can adapt and technologies can scale. Skip the people, and you risk building solutions that look great on paper but struggle in practice.

Building a Community That Lasts

Thatâ€™s why community matters so much in the SAP BTP journey. Communities create ecosystems where growth is mutualâ€”where experts share not just what they know, but also lift others to succeed. By doing so, they multiply value far beyond what technology alone can deliver.

This is why Iâ€™ve chosen to write here. My goal is to contribute to a community where knowledge flows openly and people feel empowered to innovate together. In future posts, Iâ€™ll share practical ways to accelerate BTP learning and adoption, grounded in the belief that people must always come first.

Join the Conversation

SAP BTP will continue to evolve, but one principle remains constant: people drive progress.

So, Iâ€™ll leave you with this question: In your SAP BTP journey, how have people made a difference?

Your story might be the one that inspires someone else to grow. And if nothing else, youâ€™ll save someone from endlessly googling â€œIs it still called SAP Cloud Platform orâ€¦?â€ ğŸ˜‰

entry.title: Kickstart Your SAP BTP Journey
entry.content:
All you need to know and where to start

You may have come across articles, presentations, interviews or discussions about SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). You heard the term quite often, but you might still be asking:  

  • What exactly is SAP BTP?
  • Why is SAP BTP important?
  • And how do I begin exploring SAP BTPâ€™s potential?
  • How does SAP BTP fit into the clean core strategy?

Youâ€™re now at the right place.

Whether you're a decision maker looking to drive IT strategy, an IT professional building solutions, a business user focused on innovation, or part of the academic community exploring cutting-edge technologies, this post is your launchpad into the world of SAP BTP.

Curious where you fit in? Keep reading to discover the tools, learning paths, and support SAP BTP offers for every IT role: from developers and architects to students, educators, and decision makers.

No matter your background or goals, thereâ€™s a starting point tailored just for you.

 

What Weâ€™ll Cover Here

  1. What Is SAP BTP?
  2. Why SAP BTP Matters
  3. SAP BTP and clean core
  4. Try Before You Buy: Trials & Pricing Models
  5. Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?
  6. SAP BTP Essentials: Resources for Every IT Role
  7. Stay Ahead: Strategy, Roadmaps & Updates
  8. Start building today!

 

What is SAP BTP?

SAP BTP is an intuitive, modern development and innovation platform for both professional IT and business users. It is a unified platform that brings quickly together everything you need to build any idea or business vision to life, extending, and integrating existing business applications, whether theyâ€™re SAP or not.

With self-service data discovery, modeling, planning, and analytics for business users in a governed environment, it provides integration solutions to connect and streamline applications and processes across the entire enterprise, offering pre-built business content like built-in data products, integrations, workflows, app templates, and AI services.

Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s in the toolbox:

  • App Development & Automation: Rapidly develop applications or automate processes using low-code/no-code tools or opt for professional-code development when advanced customization and control are required
  • Data & Analytics: Turn your data into decisions with built-in analytics and planning tools.
  • Integration: Connect SAP or non-SAP systems like a pro.
  • Artificial Intelligence: Infuse AI into your workflows, apps, and decisions.
  • Platform Foundation: Secure, scalable, and ready for hybrid cloud environments.

Simply put, SAP BTP enables you to innovate and stay relevant by building on established foundations.

 

Why SAP BTP Matters?

Because digital transformation is not just a trend, itâ€™s essential for adaptability and resilience, a.k.a. survival.

With SAP BTP, you can:

  • Automate repetitive tasks and free up time for real work.
  • Connect all of your systems, so they integrate.
  • Build custom apps tailored to your business needs and vision.
  • Use AI to make smarter decisions, faster.
  • Connect and harmonize all your data, eliminating data silos
  • Get mission-critical insights from your data without a background in data science

And the best part? You donâ€™t have to start from scratch.
SAP BTP offers thousands of pre-built content packages, from application or automation templates to integration flows to dashboards to AI services.

 

SAP BTP and clean core

Clean core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing agile, innovative and efficient ERP systems. The principles focus on building resilient business processes and extensions supported by seamless integration, efficient operations, and data quality.

Central to the clean core strategy are Side-by-side extensions, powered by SAP BTP.

Side-by-side extensions allow organizations to enhance their SAP landscapes without directly modifying the core SAP S/4HANA system: instead of embedding custom code within the core, new functionalities, integrations, and custom applications are developed and deployed independently on SAP BTP.

This approach leverages SAP BTP's robust services, including various runtime environments (like Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and the ABAP Environment), development tools (like SAP Business Application Studio and CAP), and critical integration services (like SAP Integration Suite and SAP Event Mesh). Connectivity is securely handled by tools like the SAP Cloud Connector for on-premise systems and the Destination Service, ensuring seamless data exchange via standard APIs and business events from the core.

 

Try Before You Buy: Free Trials & Flexible Pricing Models
Not ready to commit? No problem

SAP BTP offers a 90-day free trial with access to 30+ services.

You can explore, experiment, and learn at your own pace how to build, deploy, and integrate with a full suite of platform services.

Start here your free trial of SAP Business Technology Platform.

When you're ready to scale, youâ€™ve got options:

  • Free Tier: Build small apps, pay only for what you use.
  • Pay-As-You-Go: Great for dynamic needs and innovation projects.
  • Enterprise Agreement: Predictable pricing for known use cases.

Explore all the possibilities SAP BTP unlocks. Weâ€™ve outlined the opportunities below:

 

Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?

Thousands of organizations, from global enterprises to emerging startups, are already leveraging SAP BTP to transform their operations. Let their success inspire you.
They are using SAP BTP to:

  • Automate supply chains
  • Personalize customer experiences
  • Streamline HR processes
  • Build AI-powered finance tools ... and achieve much more.

With over 33,000 customers and 3,200 partners, you'll be in excellent company.

See how SAP BTP customers are achieving a measurable impact across industries and lines of business.

 

SAP BTP Essentials: Resources for Every IT Role

Hereâ€™s your go-to list of resources to get rolling, matched to your role:

Note: This table is a starting point. Resource-role mappings are suggestions. Feel free to explore beyond your role based on your needs and interests. Find below what each of the resources has to offer.

SAP Discovery Center - Learn about SAP BTP Services in detail:

  • Start your experience with Guided Missions to bring real life use-cases to life
  • Reference established architectures patterns to guide your design and implementation
  • Understand how SAP BTPâ€™s AI capabilities are used to infuse AI features into SAPâ€™s solution portfolio
  • Create an estimate of your services to get a first impression about the usage cost.

SAP BTP Learning - Free learning journeys tailored to your role and pace:

  • Familiarize yourself with the basic concepts of SAP BTP.
  • Get enabled.
  • Plan your implementation.
  • Prepare for your go-live.

SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Provides a central access point for architects, developers, and administrators to build and run enterprise-grade solutions on SAP BTP:

  • Decision Guides: Quickly identify the best technology options for your specific needs.
  • Reference Architectures: Explore solution templates to effectively design and build on BTP, understanding key concepts and capabilities.
  • Methodologies: Access guided approaches to boost your cloud technology maturity, spanning both technical and organizational aspects.
  • Technology Recommendations: Evaluate and choose the right implementation options across various technology domains.
  • DevOps Principles: Empower your development and operations teams to achieve greater efficiency.

SAP Business Accelerator Hub  - Kickstart your projects with ready-to-use Business Content available for SAP BTP:

  • Integration: Access over 4,000 pre-built objects, including integration flows, scripts, value mappings, and message mappings, to streamline your connections with SAP Integration Suite
  • Development & Automation: Accelerate your projects with approximately 650 pre-built workflows, automations, applications, templates, and actions ready for use with SAP Build
  • Analytics: Jump-start your data insights using pre-built dashboards, stories, and data models specifically designed for SAP BTP's analytics capabilities
  • Information: Explore a rich repository of resources, including APIs, events, CDS views, business objects, interfaces, adapters, process blueprints, and SAP-validated partner use cases.

SAP Community - Connect with fellow SAP BTP users, ask questions and share ideas, get help and help others.

 

Stay Ahead: Strategy, Roadmaps & Updates

SAP Release Navigator - Keep up with the latest innovations and updates across SAP BTP, track new features and plan your adoption.

Road Map Explorer - Discover SAPâ€™s product strategies and planned innovations with this go-to interactive tool. It highlights key advancements and offers a robust planning horizon, helping you precisely detail your transformation journey.

Strategy White Paper for SAP BTP - When you are ready to get deeper, discover more with SAPâ€™s strategy for SAP BTP.

 

Start Building today!

Start your journey today with the SAP BTP Trial or explore your first mission at the SAP Discovery Center.

Got further questions? Drop them below and letâ€™s build something amazing, together.

entry.title: Success Connect: Your People Deserve More Than Just Software - They Deserve Success
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Community!

From Chief Human Resources Officers to HRIS managers to frontline people leaders, HR professionals at every level are navigating an increasingly complex talent landscape. The pressure to create exceptional employee experiences while driving measurable business outcomes has never been greater. Your organization's success depends not just on having the right technology, but on strategically leveraging that technology to transform how you attract, develop, and retain talent. SAP Business Technology Platform and the SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite work together to help you achieve exactly that.

For Part 2 of this blog series on SAP Connect 2025, I'm excited to spotlight Success Connect 2025. It will provide CHROs with the next steps to focus on strategic workforce transformation, while delivering deep technical content for HRIS managers and HR technology professionals who implement and optimize these solutions daily.

If this is the first time you're hearing about SAP Connect 2025, read this blog first.

 

 

HR Going Beyond Traditional Boundaries

Today's HR leaders face unprecedented challenges. Regardless of your industry or organization size, you're expected to be data scientists, morale builders, strategic business partners, and technology innovatorsâ€”all while maintaining the employee experience that defines great HR. On top of that, HR leaders are also faced with major obstacles in preparing their workforce for AI. With all these rapid changes in technology, the workforceâ€™s generational differences, and your organizationâ€™s moving goals, where do you go from here?

 

By integrating, extending, and automating your SAP SuccessFactors solutions and processes, SAP Business Technology Platform doesn't just support your organizationâ€”it evolves it into what it was meant to be. This enables your existing HR processes to transform into the proactive talent strategy that drives measurable business value. Check out  SAP.com/btp-for-HR page for more in-depth information on how SAP BTP helps deliver better and more efficient HCM processes.

Here are my five must-attend sessions at Success Connect that will expand how you think about HR technology possibilities:

 

 

Your must-attend sessions at Success Connect

 

Scenario 1: Integration

 

Your Challenge: HR processes span multiple systemsâ€” the SAP SuccessFactors HCM suite and third-party applications â€”creating fragmentation that leads to inefficiencies, data errors, and poor employee experiences. Read about the related use case here. 

The Solution: Discover how SAP Integration Suite enables seamless connections between SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite and your entire HR ecosystem. Explore integration use cases for recruiting, onboarding, and data collection, plus strategies for connecting hybrid landscapes with legacy on-premises systems. See how SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh enables you to monitor your event-driven system and manage various aspects of your event-driven architecture. Learn to automate immediate responses for hiring, role changes, and other critical workforce events.

Business Impact: Interconnected HR processes eliminate manual data entry, reduce the time needed to onboard new employees by 50%, and create consistent employee experiences regardless of underlying system complexity. Event-driven integration ensures new employees have system access on day one, eliminates security risks from delayed termination processing, and creates seamless workforce transitions.

If this is you, these sessions should be on your agenda:

 

Maximizing HCM Process Efficiency with Integration Through SAP BTP | HCM1665

Tuesday Oct 7 | 11:15 AM â€“ 12:00 PM PDT

How to Use Event-Driven Integration to Collaborate in Real Time | HCM1682

 Wednesday Oct 8 | 12:30 PM â€“ 12:50 PM PDT

 

 

Scenario 2: Automation

 

Your Challenge: Your employees and HR teams spend valuable time on repetitive tasks, such as managing employee data and records, handling routine processes and more, instead of focusing on strategic HR activities that drive employee engagement and retention. Read about the related use case here. 

The Solution: Explore automation capabilities that streamline recruiting, onboarding, document management, and HR workflows. Learn how SAP BTP helps reduce manual errors while freeing your team to focus on high-value activities that directly impact employee experience.

Business Impact: HR process automation typically reduces administrative overhead by 60% while improving accuracy and employee satisfaction with HR services.

If this is you, this session should be on your agenda:

 

Increasing Employee Efficiency with Automation Capabilities in SAP BTP | HCM1671

 Wednesday Oct 8 | 10:00 AM â€“ 10:45 AM PDT

 

 

Scenario 3: Extensibility and app Development

 

Your Challenge: Your workforce needs mobile access to different HR services, but standard solutions don't address your unique requirements or user experience preferences. The existing processes are prone to errors, making it hard to gain insights from the data. Read about the full use case here. 

The Solution: Explore building a custom mobile app using SAP Build solutions. These solutions make developing an application tailored to your workforce needs intuitive, even for non-technical users. 

Business Impact: With SAP Build's low-code capabilities, a customized application can be built 10 times faster. 

If this is you, this session should be on your agenda:

 

Hands-On Lab: Creating a Custom Mobile App for HR Using SAP Build Solutions | HCM1677

  • Tuesday Oct 7 | 3:30 PM â€“ 4:45 PM PDT
  • Wednesday Oct 8 | 1:00 PM â€“ 2:15 PM PDT

Additionally, a simplified version of the hands-on lab topic of creating a mobile app is being demonstrated at the Integrate and Extend with SAP BTP demo station in the HCM area, when the show floor is open

Enhancing People Profiles with SAP Business Technology Platform | HCM1520

Wednesday Oct 8 | 2:45 PM â€“ 3:30 PM PDT

 

 

Additional sessions that should be in your agenda:

 

AI Technology, use cases and innovation

 

Road map and vision: AI in SAP SuccessFactors HCM | HCM1451

  • Tuesday Oct 7 | 11:15 AM â€“ 12:00 PM PDT
  • Wednesday Oct 8 | 2:45 PM â€“ 3:30 PM PDT

Unlocking and extending the Joule copilot with Joule Studio | HCM1571

Tuesday Oct 7 | 12:45 PM â€“ 1:30 PM PDT

Everything you need to know about AI agents for HCM | HCM1468

Tuesday Oct 7 | 2:00 PM â€“ 2:45 PM PDT

 

 Employee experience via integration and extensibility

 

Drive productivity by integrating and extending your HCM solutions | HCM1081

Tuesday Oct 7 | 4:15 PM â€“ 5:00 PM PDT

 

Technology and administration

 

Fortifying together: Best practices for partner and customer security | HCM1061

Tuesday Oct 7 | 10:00 AM â€“ 10:45 AM PDT

Simplifying your system administration to maximize business continuity | HCM1106

Tuesday Oct 7 | 2:00 PM â€“ 2:45 PM PDT

Road map and vision: Application and technology foundation | HCM1030

Tuesday Oct 7 | 3:15 PM â€“ 4:00 PM PDT

 

 

 

Register Now: Your HR Transformation Starts Here

Success Connect 2025 isn't just about learning new capabilitiesâ€”it's about positioning your HR organization to lead in the talent-driven economy that's already here. You will gain practical strategies you can implement immediately to transform your HR technology investments into competitive advantages.

Register now for Success Connect 2025 and join the community of HR leaders who are turning people technology into people success. Hereâ€™s a great blog from my colleague @rnoia  on SAP BTP for HR at SAP Connect and Success Connect 2025 summary.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud â€“ Blog #3 in the Series
entry.content:
Welcome back to my blog series on the value of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In the first two blogs, I discussed how features such as multi-model engines, infrastructure independence, and a next-generation application foundation all can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

In fact, weâ€™ve already seen powerful confirmation of the value of this database. For example, global consulting services provider CONTAX Inc. migrated to SAP HANA Cloud to gain the elasticity and scalability it needed to handle huge demands on its database resources. This modernization helped CONTAX expand its database capacity while reducing its overall memory footprint and cost by 25%.

Thatâ€™s impressive. So how can you best estimate the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud for your enterprise?

Many organizations want to migrate their database to the cloud because they want to build and deploy intelligent applications at scale. But that requires an advanced data landscape architectureâ€”a database-as-a-service (DBaaS) for modernizing your applications. Letâ€™s talk about two capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud that help you meet that need and deliver exceptional value: intelligent data tiering and multi-dimensional elastic scalability.

Intelligent data tiering

The exploding growth of business data is both a cost issue and a management challenge for your business. How can you store the data users need and make it easily accessible without busting the budget?

Traditional database technology requires that you choose between database performance and costs. Should you pay more to over-provision storage space so data can be easily persisted in case of growing demands? Or should you archive data to save money but make data harder to access?

With SAP HANA Cloud, you can strike the right balance for your business.

 Intelligent, multi-temperature data management features help you store data in tiers according to type, operational usefulness, access frequency, and scalability requirements. The database locates frequently accessed, business-critical â€œhotâ€ data in high-performance, in-memory storage, which facilitates real-time processing. â€œWarmâ€ data requiring moderate access uses disk storage. Infrequently accessed â€œcoldâ€ data can be stored in a lower-cost data lake optimized for long-term retention and compliance.

By combining tiered storage with advanced virtualization capabilities, SAP HANA Cloud reduces cost and complexity while enabling optimum overall performance. Applications and users can query data at any tier without needing to know where the data is stored. Automatic optimization based on data location and access patterns eliminates complex, costly ETL processesâ€”while supporting both operational efficiency and analytical depth. Data tiering also simplifies application development by offering one interface to multiple data tiers. Developers can use that interface to query data for applications without needing to know where the data is stored.

A recent IDC study [1] assessed database performance impacts for organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Query speed and response time improved by 31% and 29%, respectively. Backups executed 27% faster. Both data load time and recovery time were 24% faster.

â€œData is more accessible with SAP HANA Cloud,â€ said one study participant. â€œIt is also available in real time and loads far quicker than our previous environment. Our data performance has enhanced.â€

Multi-dimensional elastic scalability

Another way SAP HANA Cloud helps you balance performance and cost is by enabling elastic scalability for data processing and storage across multiple dimensions. In todayâ€™s dynamic database environments, short-term processing peaks caused by issues such as period-end reporting surges, seasonal transactions, or heavy analytics workloads can create havoc.

Elastic scalability lets you adjust compute and storage resources based on workload demands, in real time. The database ramps up resources during periods of high demand and then reduces them during low-usage times to conserve costs. Flexible resources include:

  • Performance classes, with flexible CPUs and memory ratios
  • Elastic compute nodes, on-demand resources provisioned in minutes for data-intensive OLAP workloads
  • Dynamic scalability, with individual storage tiers that allow the database to grow or shrink as needed

SAP HANA Cloud also includes elasticity features such as class-based dynamic workload routing, which automatically sends queries to the most appropriate compute resources. An ECN advisor analyzes historical workload patterns and creates optimal provisioning schedules. To prevent scaling events from disrupting application performance, SAP HANA Cloud offers built-in monitoring and workload routing capabilities.

These elastic scalability features help you respond rapidly to changing business needs, enabling optimal performance without over provisioning resources. These features make data more accessible to users while reducing infrastructure complexity. Together, they can help you drive operational agility and cost-effective resource management.

With these benefits in mind, IDC evaluated the infrastructure costs of surveyed companies that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Using its business value methodology, IDC concluded that the infrastructure costs of an SAP HANA Cloud environment were 20% less than a comparable database environment over a three-year period.

According to one study participant operating in the retail industry, â€œSAP HANA Cloud has given my organization the ability to scale and reduce redundancy, which are significant benefits.â€

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the next blog to learn how native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines database administrator duties can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.

Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

 [1] â€œThe Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,â€ IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: SAP OData to MCP Server running on BTP
entry.content:
Transform your SAP S/4HANA or ECC system into a conversational AI interface by exposing all OData services as dynamic MCP tools. This enables natural language interactions with your ERP data:

  • "Show me 10 banks" â†’ Automatically queries the Bank entity with $top=10
  • "Update bank with ID 1 to have street number 5" â†’ Executes PATCH operation on Bank entity
  • "Create a new customer with name John Doe" â†’ Performs POST to Customer entity
  • "List all purchase orders from this week" â†’ Applies $filter for date range on PurchaseOrder entity

Prerequisite

CloudFoundry CLI installed: https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html 

BTP Account with CloudFoundry active and a space:

Cloud Connector with principal propagation

Install

Go to the GitHub repository: https://github.com/lemaiwo/btp-sap-odata-to-mcp-server

Click on the green button â€œCodeâ€ and copy the url:

git clone https://github.com/lemaiwo/btp-sap-odata-to-mcp-server.git
cd btp-sap-odata-to-mcp-server

Copy the example.env file into a .env file and configure it to your needs, find more information in the Configure and Options section

npm run build:btp
cf login -a <cf api endpoint of BTP>
npm run deploy:btp

Once deployed, you'll find it in the list of applications in BTP CloudFoundry:

 

Configure

Create two destinations:

  • one with principal propagation to have SSO which will be used to executed OData queries with the user JWT 
  • one with a technical user that is used while starting the server to scan the OData services of the system and already preload the metadata

Technical destination:

Destination with principal propagation:

 

Copy the .env.example file to .env and configure it as follows to have the recommended settings but replace the ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS with your preferred selection:

SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_SYSTEM_TECH
SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_SYSTEM_SSO
# SAP_DESTINATION_NAME=your-own-destination

LOG_LEVEL=debug

# OData Service Discovery Configuration Examples
# Method 1: Allow all services (use * or 'true')
ODATA_ALLOW_ALL=false

# Method 2: Specify service patterns (supports glob patterns)
# Comma-separated list of patterns
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=*TASKPROCESSING*,*BOOK*,*FLIGHT*,*TRAVEL*,*TRVEXP*,*TRAVELAGENCY*,*TRAVELAGENCYSRV*,*TRAVELAPPROVALS*,*TRAVELAPPROVALS_SRV*,*ZBP*,*ZTRANSPORT*,*ZBC_UI_PARAM_E_CDS*

# Method 3: Use JSON array for more complex patterns
# ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=["ZBP*", "ZTRANSPORT*", "/^Z.*_CDS$/"]

# Method 4: Use regex patterns (enclose in forward slashes)
# ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=/^Z(BP|TRANSPORT).*/

# Exclusion patterns (services to exclude even if they match inclusion patterns)
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_TEST*,*_TEMP*

# Maximum number of services to discover (prevents system overload)
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=50

# Discovery mode: 'all', 'whitelist', 'regex'
ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE=whitelist

Use

Copy the url of the application

Go to your AI Agent/LLM, eg.: Claude AI desktop, open tools and click on Manage connectors:

Click on "Add custom connector" :

Give the MCP server a name and paste the url of the application in BTP with â€œ/mcpâ€ added to it:

It might take some time before it is shown. For some reason, Claude Dekstop first tryâ€™s to connect without authentication and then takes some time before showing the system:

After some time it should become visible:

Once the system is visible, you can click on the connect button. This will redirect you to BTP to login. First time it might ask you to login to claude, after that it should give you the sap login or your corporate idp, if not, try clicking a second time on connect:

Once authenticated, youâ€™ll find your SAP system in the set of tools:

Start asking questions:

Options

A key capability is deploying the MCP Server to different spaces within the same subaccount. This lets you set up multiple MCP servers with different configurations. For example, you can configure an MCP server for each SAP system in your landscape, or set up one for each domain â€” such as one MCP server for all HR OData services, another for all Materials Management (MM) OData services, and so on.

Core Configuration

Configuration Option

Description

Example Values

Notes

SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME

SAP destination for service discovery (uses technical user)

SAP_SYSTEM_TECH

Used for metadata operations

SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME

SAP destination for data operations (uses JWT forwarding for SSO)

SAP_SYSTEM_SSO

Used for actual data access with user context

SAP_DESTINATION_NAME

Single destination for both discovery and execution

SAP_SYSTEM

Legacy option for backward compatibility

MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE

Defines how tools are organized in the registry

hierarchical (default)
flat

IMPORTANT: hierarchical exposes all OData services as just 4 tools. flat exposes EVERY CRUD operation for EACH entity as separate tools. While this can exceed limits with many services, flat mode can be beneficial for small, focused deployments

LOG_LEVEL

Controls the verbosity of application logging

error, warn, info, debug

Default is info

DISABLE_READ_ENTITY_TOOL

Disables ReadEntity tool registration

true, false (default)

Useful for performance with large datasets

 

âš ï¸CRITICAL CONFIGURATION NOTE: The MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE setting has a major impact on tool exposure:

  • hierarchical mode (recommended for most cases):
      - Exposes all OData services through just 4 unified tools
      - Keeps the tool count manageable regardless of service count
      - Requires agents to first discover services, then entities

  • flat mode:
      - Creates individual tools for EVERY CRUD operation for EACH entity
      - Can quickly exceed system limits with many services (hundreds/thousands of tools)
      - Significantly increases token consumption
      - HOWEVER: Can be advantageous for small, focused deployments (1-2 services)
        where direct tool names like "Create_BusinessPartner" or "Update_SalesOrder"
        make it easier for agents to find and use the right tool without discovery steps

 

OData Service Discovery Configuration

Configuration Option

Description

Example Values

Notes

ODATA_ALLOW_ALL

Allow discovery of all available services

true, false (default)

Use * or true to enable

ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS

Specify which services to include using patterns

See examples section

Supports multiple pattern formats

ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS

Services to exclude even if they match inclusion patterns

*_TEST*,*_TEMP*

Comma-separated list

ODATA_MAX_SERVICES

Maximum number of services to discover

50 (example)

Prevents system overload

ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE

Controls how service discovery works

all, whitelist, regex

Determines pattern matching behavior

 

Service Pattern Examples

Pattern Type

Example

Description

Glob Patterns

*TASKPROCESSING*,*BOOK*

Use wildcards (*) to match multiple services

Specific Services

*TRAVEL*,*TRAVELAGENCY*

Target specific service names

Prefix Matching

ZBP*,ZTRANSPORT*

Match services starting with specific prefixes

JSON Array

["ZBP*", "ZTRANSPORT*"]

Complex patterns in JSON format

Regex Patterns

/^Z(BP|TRANSPORT).*/

Regular expressions in forward slashes

 

Configuration Examples

Example 1: Enterprise Setup with Separate Authentication

Use Case: Large enterprise SAP landscape with strict security requirements

# Separate destinations for security
SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_ECC_TECH_USER
SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_ECC_SSO

# Use hierarchical mode for many services
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=hierarchical

# Whitelist specific business services
ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE=whitelist
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=*SALESORDER*,*PURCHASEORDER*,*BUSINESSPARTNER*,*MATERIAL*
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_TEST*,*_TEMP*,*_DEV*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=100

# Production logging
LOG_LEVEL=info

Example 2: Development Environment - All Services

Use Case: Development/sandbox environment where developers need access to all services

# Single destination for simplicity
SAP_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_DEV_SYSTEM

# Hierarchical for many services
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=hierarchical

# Allow all services in dev
ODATA_ALLOW_ALL=true
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_ARCHIVE*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=200

# Debug logging for development
LOG_LEVEL=debug

Example 3: Focused HR Service - Flat Mode

Use Case: Small MCP server dedicated to HR operations with direct tool access

# HR-specific destination
SAP_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_HR_SYSTEM

# Flat mode for direct tool access
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=flat

# Only HR-related services
ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE=whitelist
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=*EMPLOYEE*,*ORGUNIT*,*TIMESHEET*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=5

# Standard logging
LOG_LEVEL=info

# Note: This creates tools like:

# - Create_Employee

# - Update_TimeSheet

# - Delete_OrgUnit

# Making it easy for agents to directly use HR operations

 

Example 4: Custom Services with Regex Patterns

Use Case: Organization with custom-developed Z* and Y* services

# Technical user for custom services
SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_CUSTOM_TECH
SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_CUSTOM_SSO

# Hierarchical for scalability
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=hierarchical

# Regex pattern for custom services
ODATA_DISCOVERY_MODE=regex
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=/^[ZY].*_SRV$/
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_OLD*,*_BACKUP*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=75

# Info level for production
LOG_LEVEL=info
DISABLE_READ_ENTITY_TOOL=false

Example 5: Multi-Domain Setup with Complex Patterns

Use Case: Multiple business domains with specific service requirements

# Separate auth for compliance
SAP_DISCOVERY_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_PROD_METADATA
SAP_EXECUTION_DESTINATION_NAME=SAP_PROD_USER_AUTH

# Hierarchical for large service count
MCP_TOOL_REGISTRY_TYPE=hierarchical

# Complex pattern matching using JSON array
ODATA_SERVICE_PATTERNS=["*FI_*", "*CO_*", "*MM_*", "*SD_*", "/^Z(FI|CO|MM|SD).*/"]
ODATA_EXCLUSION_PATTERNS=*_TEST*,*_TMP*,*_BCK*,*_DECOMMISSIONED*
ODATA_MAX_SERVICES=150

# Standard production settings
LOG_LEVEL=info
DISABLE_READ_ENTITY_TOOL=false

# This configuration covers:

# - Finance (FI) services

# - Controlling (CO) services 

# - Materials Management (MM) services

# - Sales & Distribution (SD) services

# - Custom services for these modules

 

Tool Registry Mode Comparison

Scenario 1: Large SAP Deployment
10 OData services, each with 5 entities:

hierarchical mode: 4 tools total (search, discover, schema, execute)

flat mode: 10 services Ã— 5 entities Ã— 4 CRUD = 200 individual tools âŒ Not recommended

 

Scenario 2: Focused Deployment
1 Business Partner service with 3 entities (Partner, Address, Contact):

hierarchical mode: 4 generic tools (requires discovery steps)

flat mode: 12 specific tools like "Create_BusinessPartner", "Update_Address" âœ… Could be optimal

 

ğŸ’¡RECOMMENDATION:
â€¢ Use hierarchical for standard deployments and when exposing multiple services
â€¢ Consider flat only for small, focused MCP servers (1-2 services) where you want to keep the MCP server small and optimize for direct tool discovery by agents
â€¢ Always exclude test/temporary services in production environments
â€¢ Set appropriate ODATA_MAX_SERVICES limits to prevent performance issues

entry.title: SAP BTP AI Best Practices: A Deep Dive into Key Technical Foundations
entry.content:
In our first post of this campaign - SAP BTP AI Best Practices: Your Ultimate Guide for Building AI Solutions - we introduced the initiative that brings together technical recommendations, architectural patterns, and practical insights to help customers and partners successfully design, build, and operate AI solutions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

These BTP AI Best Practices are accessible from the Discovery Center. To get more details, you can check SAP BTP Guidance Framework and the SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Introduction Post.

In this post, weâ€™re going to focus on six best practices that are fundamental for building reliable, secure, and scalable Generative AI scenarios on SAP BTP.

  • Access to Generative AI Models

Access management is one of the first challenges when working with Generative AI. SAP BTP provides secure connectivity to a wide range of AI models, ensuring compliance with enterprise standards while enabling flexibility for innovation. Following this best practice guarantees:

  • Controlled usage of models in productive environments
  • Alignment with governance and audit requirements
  • Seamless integration of AI capabilities into SAP applications and custom extensions
  • Prompt Templating

Well-structured prompts are critical to consistent AI outcomes. Prompt templating best practices allows developers and business users to:

  • Reuse standardized prompt structures across multiple scenarios
  • Improve reproducibility of AI responses
  • Facilitate collaboration by separating prompt logic from business logic

By adopting prompt templating, organizations reduce variability and ensure higher quality outputs when leveraging Generative AI.

  • Data Masking

Data privacy remains a cornerstone of AI adoption. Data masking is key to protecting sensitive information before it is processed by AI services. This best practice addresses:

  • Anonymization of personal and business-critical data
  • Compliance with GDPR and other data protection regulations
  • Enabling safe experimentation without risking data leaks

Applying data masking ensures that AI innovations can move forward responsibly and securely.

  • Content Filtering

AI systems need guardrails to prevent misuse or harmful outputs. Content filtering best practices help organizations:

  • Detect and block inappropriate or non-compliant AI-generated content
  • Maintain trust in AI-driven user experiences
  • Align with corporate and ethical AI principles

This step is crucial for making AI solutions both safe and enterprise-ready.

  • Vector RAG â€“ Embedding

A solid embedding strategy is the foundation of effective Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). This best practice covers how to:

  • Represent domain-specific knowledge in a vectorized form
  • Optimize embeddings for retrieval efficiency and relevance
  • Enable your AI models to ground responses in enterprise data
  • Vector RAG â€“ Query Pipeline

The query pipeline orchestrates how user queries interact with the vector store. Following this best practice helps you:

  • Ensure accurate and contextually relevant retrieval
  • Implement scalable and efficient query flows
  • Reduce hallucinations by grounding AI outputs in trusted enterprise data

Meet the experts who shaped this initiative

The SAP BTP AI Best Practices initiative is led by Markus Albrecht, SVP & GM, ASC BTP Solution Area, and developed in collaboration with a core team of experts committed to helping developers succeed with AI on SAP BTP.

By combining diverse expertise, hands-on experience, and deep technical knowledge, this team has ensured that the best practices are not only practical and enterprise-ready, but also closely aligned with real-world customer needs.

You Might Also be Interested In

These six best practices are just a selection from the broader collection available. Together, they form the technical backbone of secure and scalable AI adoption on SAP BTP. Visit all BTP AI Best Practices .

In the upcoming posts, we will continue exploring additional best practices in depth. In the meantime, you can dive even deeper through dedicated videos available on the official SAP YouTube channel, where our experts walk you through the concepts, use cases, and demos behind these best practices.

Feedback on SAP BTP AI Best Practices can be provided here.

Stay Tuned

This blog post is part of our ongoing series, Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework, where we spotlight key resources that help you build smarter, faster, and with more confidence on SAP BTP. In the next post, weâ€™ll continue diving into different areas of the frameworkâ€”so stay tuned and follow along as we explore more ways to turn ideas into enterprise-grade solutions.

entry.title: Build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAPâ€™s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology
entry.content:
What is SAP BTP Guidance Framework: The Guidance Framework provides clear direction and a structured approach to adopting SAP technologies. With this guidance, you can develop intelligent applications using advanced analytics, equipping your organization with a robust foundation to support agile innovation. For more details read this blog. 

In this blog post, we will look into how to build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAPâ€™s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. You can find this Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology pillar under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. 

Itâ€™s imperative that in todayâ€™s economy, data is more than just numbersâ€”itâ€™s the foundation of innovation, strategy, and growth backed by AI. Yet many organizations still struggle to unlock the full potential of their data and give it purpose. SAPâ€™s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a structured, four-phase approach that helps enterprises transform raw data into actionable insights while building a strong data-driven culture. 

The Four Phases of SAPâ€™s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology 

1. Scoping & Baseline Analysis: In this phase you can set the foundation by: 

  • Defining the scope of investigation across business processes, organizational units, and data domains. 
  • Assessing current data architecture and capabilities. 
  • Identifying gaps, pain points, and opportunities for improvement. 

Benefit of this phase is that your business will have a clear baseline architecture, capability assessment, and prioritized opportunities. 

2. Business Outcomes & Solution Requirements: the focus in this phase shifts to aligning data with measurable business goals such as:  

  • Define specific, data-driven business outcomes. 
  • Analyze use cases that trace how raw data transforms into business value. 
  • Identify required data products and map end-to-end integration flows. 

This phase allows to clearly define business outcome definitions and solution context diagrams. 

 3. Capability Map & Solution Architecture: this phase transforms requirements into a target architecture by: 

  • Developing a capability map using SAP BTP Maturity Assessment 
  • Explore architecture options through traditional capability mapping or solution diagrams from the SAP Discovery Center. 
  • Validate the preferred architecture with proof-of-concepts. 

With this phase the target solution architecture is validated through capability mapping and pilots. 

 4. Data Governance & Roadmaps: this final phase ensures long-term sustainability: 

  • Conduct a maturity assessment for data governance and organizational roles. 
  • Define roles such as Chief Data Officer, Data Steward, and Governance Manager. 
  • Build a roadmap with clear clusters (e.g., implementation, operations, security). 

The key benefit of this phase is to define Data governance framework, organizational structure, and a roadmap for execution. 

What makes SAPâ€™s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology stand out is that itâ€™s not just about technologyâ€”itâ€™s about data, people and processes. By integrating governance, roles, and organizational change management, it ensures that data initiatives arenâ€™t just implemented but also adopted across the enterprise. For organizations aiming to thrive in a data-driven economy, SAPâ€™s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology provides more than a roadmapâ€”it delivers a proven framework for turning data into business value and give it purpose. By combining architecture best practices with governance and cultural adoption, it helps enterprises evolve from simply managing data to truly innovating with it. 

To read more about SAPâ€™s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology check out SAP Discovery Center. 

â€œOrganizations that adopt this framework position themselves to lead in the AI-driven economyâ€

entry.title: SAP BTP Guidance Framework: Center of Expertise (CoE), Administration and DevOps
entry.content:
As outlined in the blog post SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators from Cecily Sorenson (@cecilysorenson), the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a practical framework for anyone using SAP BTP. In this blog post, let's focus especially on the organizational setup and the role and tasks of an administrator. 

Overview of SAP BTP Guidance Framework - and focus of this blog post

Here, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework brings a lot to get you started! 

 

Organizational Setup 

One main question faced in almost every SAP BTP project is on the best organizational setup to ease a smooth onboarding, reduce time to value and to operate the platform effectively. One key aspect can be the founding of a central platform engineering team or a Center of Expertise (CoE) that is responsible for such topics as account operations, infrastructure, central governance and compliance - and for driving the overall cloud adoption across the organization. 

A CoE can make the difference and help your cloud development teams to transition towards a cloud-centric mindset and processes, as the provided guidance allows them to focus more on providing business value without having to bother about finding, implementing and running the right infrastructure and processes. 

Therefore, it should be no surprise that the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers guidance here as well, in the form of the SAP BTP Center of Expertise (CoE) Guide. 

The guide provides a comprehensive framework for establishing and scaling an SAP BTP CoE. For example, it gives a definition of a CoE, outlines a corresponding maturity model, explains roles and responsibilities, and gives practical guidance on how to implement it along the lifecycle. 

Overview of maturity model explained in the SAP BTP CoE Guide

 

Administrating the Platform and the Lifecycle 

To learn more about actual tasks and responsibilities for administrating the platform itself and for handling the lifecycle of your applications and use cases running on it, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers the SAP BTP Administrator's Guide. 

Understand basic concepts and tasks, before benefitting from guidance and best practices along topics such as: 

  • Your account model 
  • Delivering your applications and changes towards your runtime with the right mix of agility and control 
  • Operating your applications on SAP BTP, with a combination of central observability (to get aware of how your business scenarios are behaving) and local observability tools for root cause analysis in case of issues or performance degradations 

This also comprises check lists, examples and guidance. For example, hereâ€™s an example for an individual account model: 

Picture of an exemplary account model for SAP BTP

 

DevOps with SAP BTP 

When transitioning to the cloud, you want to benefit from modern development principles in the spirit of DevOps. But how does this fit to stricter boundary conditions faced in an enterprise environment? 

Here, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework also has you covered - by offering a description how to enable your development teams to benefit from tight feedback loops offered by automated build and test pipelines ("Continuous Integration") in combination with the right level of control for the delivery towards production. 

Overview of DevOps approach with SAP BTP

For this, your development teams can use pipeline templates to set up a running build and test pipeline for typical SAP BTP development use cases - thanks to our opinionated "Pipeline-as-a-Service" approach, they can set them up in minutes and run them with crucially reduced cognitive load. These pipelines then can qualify the development changes in terms of provided functionality, usage of outdated libraries, code issues, and other compliance-relevant aspects, as needed by your business. 

As soon as your development teams come up with correspondingly qualified release candidates, they can easily switch on in the pipeline the automated handover of the changes into a central, reliable transport and change management approach. Here, your administration team can centrally define delivery landscapes, including permissions on who is allowed to come up and handle changes where and a central log file for auditing reasons. This can be decoupled from the development teams who only need to know the entry node to the delivery, using a clearly defined hand-over process from qualified agile development into controlled delivery towards production.  

With a simple integration of transport management into SAP's central operation platforms, this can even be extended to central change management processes, to handle interdependencies of changes from different environments by centrally orchestrating their propagation across SAP BTP, SAP S/4HANA, or SAP cloud solutions. All this can be enriched with additional release planning and management capabilities. 

 

Summary 

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework has a lot to offer also for administrators â€“ from a framework to forge your organizational setup to guidance on how to handle the lifecycle of your applications and use cases on SAP BTP and on how to combine agile development with the right level of control over changes in your runtime environment. 

If you should have feedback on the documents and offerings mentioned above, please let us know â€“ ideally by providing feedback in SAP Help Portal, as described for example here: SAP BTP Documentation Goes GitHub - New Collaborat... - SAP Community

entry.title: Introducing SAP HANA Cloud on SAP Cloud Infrastructure
entry.content:
We are pleased to share that SAP HANA Cloud is now generally available on SAP BTP powered by SAP Cloud Infrastructure. This new deployment option complements our existing offerings on hyperscaler platforms, addressing the growing demand for technological independence, local compliance, and data control.

About SAP Cloud Infrastructure

SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI) is SAP's own Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) platform, operated from SAP data centers around the globe. Built on OpenStack APIs, it provides hyperscale-like capabilities including compute, storage, and networking. Originally designed to run SAP cloud applications with high scalability, resilience, compliance, and security, SCI now also supports selected customer and partner workloads. To explore the platform and its features, visit the SAP Cloud Infrastructure Documentation.

How the new deployment fits into SAP's multi-cloud strategy

SAP gives customers the flexibility to run SAP HANA Cloud on the infrastructure that best meets their needs. Today, it's available on the leading hyperscalersâ€”Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform, and Alibaba Cloudâ€”leveraging our partners' global reach and modern infrastructure. See SAP HANA Cloud data centers.

By adding SAP Cloud Infrastructure as a deployment option alongside the hyperscalers, we give customers even more choice and flexibility, while meeting requirements for technological autonomy, data residency, and access control in the public cloud.

First region and initial scope

SAP HANA Cloud is now live in the SAP BTP Europe (Frankfurt) region on SCI. This cloud-in-country deployment keeps customer and backup data local, ensuring data residency and compliance.

Operating in EU Access mode, the SCI-based deployment restricts the processing of personally identifiable customer data to SAP delivery units located within the European Economic Area (EEA) and Switzerland, giving customers enhanced control and data protection.

On SCI, SAP HANA Cloud delivers the same capabilities and benefits as on hyperscalers*, along with the same SLAs and pricing models, ensuring a consistent experience regardless of deployment choice.

What's next?

SAP HANA Cloud is expanding alongside SAP BTP into new SCI regions. Additional SCI regions are planned for upcoming releasesâ€”check the latest SAP HANA Cloud data center availability in SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Summary

With SAP HANA Cloud, customers can choose the infrastructure provider that best fits their businessâ€”either a partner hyperscaler or SAP itself. The first SAP BTP region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is Europe (Frankfurt). With EU-Access, in-country hosting, and enterprise-grade SLAs, this region provides compliance, security, and reliability, serving the specific needs of German and European customers.

*Restrictions at GA: (1) SAP HANA Cloud, Data lake Relational Engine, (2) Joule in SAP HANA Cloud Central, (3) Customer-managed encryption keys (CMK), and (4) memory sizes larger than 7.5 TB.

entry.title: Issue and Send Verifiable Credentials
entry.content:
In the evolving landscape of digital ecosystems, verifiable credentials (VCs) have emerged as a powerful tool for establishing trust and enabling secure data sharing. This article outlines the process by which an issuer can create and issue a verifiable credential with SAPs BTP service Decentralized Identity Verification based on a predefined schema, ensuring consistency and authenticity. Following issuance, the credential is securely transferred to the holder, who can use it to participate in a dataspace. For example, within the Catena-X dataspace - a collaborative network enabling trusted data sharing in the automotive and manufacturing sectors - the holder could present their VC to identify themselves in a data sharing use case, ensuring secure and seamless interaction.

Pre-Conditions for Issuance 

Before issuing a verifiable credential, several pre-conditions related to the participating entities, credential configuration, and schema setup must be fulfilled.

  1. A Holder Tenant with an Identity (DID) and Trust List Configuration. The holder, who will receive and own the verifiable credential, must have a valid Decentralized Identifier (DID). This DID uniquely represents the holder within the system, enabling them to securely interact with the issuer and verifiers. Additionally, the issuerâ€™s DID must be added to the holderâ€™s trust list. The trust list is critical as it ensures that the holder only accepts verifiable credentials from selected issuers. For example, in Catena-X, this ensures that only accredited organizations acting as trusted credential issuers can issue verifiable credentials to participants.
  2. An Issuer Tenant with an Identity (DID). The issuer, as mentioned earlier, must have a valid DID representing their secure digital identity. This DID is essential for signing and legitimizing the verifiable credentials, allowing other participants in the ecosystem to independently validate their authenticity and trustworthiness. 
  3. A Schema for the Verifiable Credential. The verifiable credential should adhere to a defined schema that specifies its structure and attributes. The schema serves as a standardized blueprint, ensuring that the data within the credential such as names, dates, or unique identifiers is understood and interoperable across all parties in the ecosystem. 
  4. Configure the Issuer: Once the schema is created, the issuer must configure the credential type that they will issue based on that schema. For each credential type the issuer can specify whether the credential requests are processed automatically or manually and if it is tied to its predefined schema. 

Issue Verifiable Credentials

  1. Navigate to credential section and click on the Issue button to start the issuance process.
  2. Configure meta data of the verifiable credential (validity settings and choose signing dentity)


    • Set Expiration: Enter the expiration date and time for the VC (how long the credential will be valid)
    • Revocation List (Optional): If the credential should be revocable, enable the option to assign it to a revocation list and select the appropriate revocation list if more than one exists.
    • Signing Identity: Select the DID (Decentralized Identifier) under your control that will be used to sign the credential. 

  3. Add additional contexts (advanced): Additional contexts allow interoperability with extended schemas or domain-specific vocabularies.

  4. Define credential details


    • Select a credential type supported by your issuer, published via the issuer metadata endpoint. These types can be configured in the issuer settings. Holders may only accept specific credential types from your issuer, so choose accordingly.
    • Select Schema: Choose the schema that defines the structure and required attributes of the credential. The holderâ€™s wallet will use this schema to validate and display the credential.
    • Fill in Mandatory Attributes: Based on the schema, a dynamic form will be displayed. Enter all required attributes (e.g., name, date of birth, license number). Ensure all fields marked as mandatory are filled; incomplete credentials may be rejected by the holder. Add any additional, non-mandatory attributes as needed.

  5. Finalize verifiable credential:


    • Immediate signing of the verifiable credential or in a later point in time
    • Immediate or deferred offer: Decide if the credential should be offered to the holder immediately after signing or stored for future delivery.

The verifiable credential is now created and can be sent directly to the holder, or, if preferred, stored and delivered upon the holderâ€™s request at a later time. All issued credentials are visible to the issuer within the wallet, allowing the issuer to select an issued credential in the future for purposes such as revocation or re-offering to the holder.

API

The same process described in the user interface can also be performed programmatically using the API, which provides an endpoint for the combined creation, signing, and offering of credentials in a single call, or, alternatively, allows you to perform these steps individually with separate API calls.

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/credentials
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "application": "Dataspace",
    "payload": {
      "offer" : {
        "content": {
            "@context": [
                "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/v1",
                "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/examples/v1"
            ],
            "name": "BPN",
            "description": "BPN",
            "expirationDate": "2025-11-25T16:51:22.000Z",
            "type": [
                "BpnCredential"
            ],
            "issuer": "{issuerDID}",
            "credentialSubject": {
                "id": "{holderDID}",
                "bpn": "BPNL000000002"
            },
            "credentialStatus": {
                "id": "{revocation list}",
                "type": "StatusList2021"
            }            
        }, 
        "signature": {
          "proofMechanism": "external",
          "proofType": "jwt"
        }
      }
    }
}

Next step:

entry.title: Transferring Verifiable Credentials with the Eclipse Dataspace Decentralized Claims Protocol (DCP)
entry.content:
In the era of Self-sovereign Identity (SIS), verifiable credentials (VCs) are becoming a cornerstone. Organizations and individuals can now issue, request, and present attestations  without relying on a central authority, enabled by emerging standards and protocols such as the Decentral Claims Protocol (DCP). This blog post explores two core ways VCs are transferred from an issuer wallet tenant to a holder wallet tenant using Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) focusing on automation options available to both issuers and holders.

 

Two VC Transfer Patterns

With DCP, there are two main patterns for moving a verifiable credential from the issuer's environment to the holder's:

Holder-Initiated Credential Request

Holder requests VCs:

  • The holder launches their VC request app and picks the issuer from which they wish to request credentials.
  • The app pulls published credential types (from the issuer's metadata endpoint), ensuring the holder can only request credentials the issuer offers. 

     
  • The users selects the credential types to be requested
  • Next, the holder selects which identity to use (think multiple DIDs or personas in their wallet).
  • A request for the selected credential type(s), tied to the chosen identity, is dispatched to the issuer.

 

API to Request VCs

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/requestCredentials/{app_name}
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "requestedCredentials": [
    {
      "credentialType": "BpnCredential",
      "format": "vcdm11_jwt"
    }
  ],
  "issuerDid": "{issuerDID}",
  "holderDid": "{holderDID}"
}

 

Issuer processes credential requests:

The issuer receives the request in their inbox. They review, approve, and send back the requested VC(s) to the holder. Alternatively, they may have to first create the credential before sending it.

Automation Option: Issuers can preconfigure their wallet to auto-respond to requests - if the VC is already ready. However, if credentials are not yet generated, or if the holder requests a set of credentials where not all are available, manual intervention is required.

Holder receives VCs:

Once complete, the holder receives the VC, visible in the credential overview section of their admin app. 


 

API to Respond to VC Requests

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

Issuer Get Received Credential Requests

GET {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialRequestsReceived
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

 

Response to VC Request -> Send Response to Request

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialRequestsReceived/{requestId}/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

 

Issuer-Initiated Credential Offer

Sometimes, the issuer wants to proactively notify holders that a credential is available or due for a refresh (e.g., before expiration or after key rotation). This issuing pattern is essential for refreshing credentials (e.g., after expiration or key revocation) because the issuer can push a new offer seamlessly, keeping the holder's status up to date with minimal friction.

Issuer sends offer

The issuer navigates their app to the relevant issued VC, opens the action menu, and sends a credential offer to the selected holder. The offer notifies the holder that a credential is prepped for them and can be retrieved.

Holder receives offer

The holder's wallet receives the offer. Here, behavior depends on their wallet's configuration:

  • Manual: The holder reviews the offer and chooses to make a credential request to receive it.
  • Automated: If the holder has marked the issuer as trusted with auto-accept enabled, the wallet will automatically convert the offer into a credential request and handle the entire transfer without manual clicks.

API to Offer VCs

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

 

POST {div_wallet_srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialOffers/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "credentials": [
    "{vcId}"
  ]
}

 

Flexible Automation for Different Needs

A core strength of DIV is its support for both manual and automated flows. Depending on policy, user preference, and business process, any step on either issuer or holder side can be handled by a human or managed entirely by the walletâ€™s auto-configuration. In highly regulated or sensitive use-cases, both sides might want maximum manual review steps before issuing or accepting credentials. In high-scale, low-touch environments, the entire process can be embedded and fully automated.

 

Summary

Decentralized identity verification, enables seamless, secure transfer of verifiable credentials across wallet tenants. Whether initiated by holders seeking new credentials or by proactive issuers keeping credentials fresh, DCP allows maximum flexibility for both manual and automated workflows letting each participant tailor the process to their risk profile and user experience needs.

Read more

  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Dataspaces
  • SAP help: Requesting VCs, Offering VCs
  • API documentation in detail
  • Decentralized Claims Protocol
